challenges.description: A great way to build a fast and clean vehicle is to use an electric motor powered from batteries. Whether the motor is a cordless drill or from an old garage door opener, you can convert the rotating energy into a drive belt that moves your wheels.
challenges.title: Build an Electric Vehicle

challenges.description: Soap Box Cars are homemade vehicles that use only gravity to move – no engine. Make a Soap Box Car with plywood and wagon wheels, or get ambitious – with fiberglass frames and ball bearing hubs. A steering system and good breaks are also important features.
challenges.title: Build a Soap Box Car

challenges.description: Boats are a great way to transport heavy loads, such as people or goods, across a body of water. If it floats and carries a load without sinking into the water, then it's probably a boat.
challenges.title: Make A Boat

challenges.description: Go-Karts come in all shapes and sizes. Most use a gasoline powered engine, although a large electric motor can work as well. You just need a strong frame, four wheels, and a motor to power it all. The rest is up to you.
challenges.title: Build A Go-Kart

challenges.description: Railbikes (or Draisines) are bikes that can ride on abandoned train tracks. They are great ways to travel without any other vehicles getting in your way, just as long as you make sure the rails you are on are absolutely not in use.
challenges.title: Build A Railbike

challenges.description: The first step of any great adventure: cram your stuff into a suitcase! Show us your best packing strategies to fit all your stuff into one bag with a video or photo.
challenges.title: Pack a Suitcase

challenges.description: Draw a map or write out a plan for your dream vacation. Make sure to include a list of events or sights you want to see along the way. Share with a photo or a video explanation.
challenges.title: Plan a Dream Trip

challenges.description: Before traveling to a new country, every traveler should know how to speak to the people who live there. Learn how to greet someone in a foreign language and share it with a video.
challenges.title: Learn a Foreign Greeting

challenges.description: Everyone loves getting mail, and postcards are a great way to remember a trip. Find an awesome postcard and send it to a friend, family, or even the DIY office! Share a pic of it before you send it off. (Make sure to cover any full names and addresses!)
challenges.title: Send a Postcard

challenges.description: A travel journal is a scrapbook of memories. It can contain almost anything including writing, pictures, drawings, or souvenirs that you've collected on your journey. In a video or series of photos, show us a few of your favorite pages from your travel journal.
challenges.title: Keep a Travel Journal

challenges.description: A souvenir is a keepsake that represents a great adventure or travel experience. Souvenirs can be objects you've purchased, found, or even made. Share your collection with a photo or a video. Make sure to label or explain where each piece came from!
challenges.title: Collect Souvenirs

challenges.description: There's a whole world of unique and tasty treats out there. Find an interesting or foreign food you've never tried before, then make a video explaining what it is and how it tastes.
challenges.title: Review a Foreign Snack

challenges.description: Traveling by bike is a great way to explore an area—it's easier to travel trails, see the sights, and experience a new place just like the locals. Share a picture of you with your bike in an awesome location.
challenges.title: Tour by Bike

challenges.description: There's nothing like the salty smell of the ocean. Relax on the beach, build a castle, or go for a dip. Share your adventure with a photo or a video. Ponds and lakes don't count for this challenge!
challenges.title: Swim in an Ocean

challenges.description: Geocaching is an outdoor activity where participants use a GPS to follow coordinates and find hidden treasure boxes called "geocaches." There are millions of geocaches hidden all over the world—what kind of cool stuff will you find?
challenges.title: Go Geocaching

challenges.description: It takes a brave and seasoned explorer to explore dark caves. Share a video or photo of you deep underground with your caving gear!
challenges.title: Go Spelunking

challenges.description: Every adventure can be exciting, from trips to the grocery store to road trips to a cruise across the ocean. The next time you go on a trip, record where you go, what you see, and what you do while you're there. Edit together a brief documentary
challenges.title: Make a Travel Documentary

challenges.description: Either by hiking or rock-climbing, you've got to get to the top somehow! Share a picture or video showing off the view from the top of your climb.
challenges.title: Climb a Mountain

challenges.description: What's your favorite public place? Take a photo or video of a great public place, making sure to show the features that make it so amazing.
challenges.title: Find Great Public Places

challenges.description: Does your street need a clearer cross walk, bike lane or stop line? Use temporary chalk to make your neighborhood safer.
challenges.title: Chalk in Street Improvements

challenges.description: Use a game like Sim City or Minecraft to make a city with at least three buildings.
challenges.title: Build a City in a Game

challenges.description: Design a park you think people will enjoy. Tell us in words or pictures what makes it great!
challenges.title: Design a Park

challenges.description: Many urbanists have thought about ideal neighborhood layout, including short blocks and gridded streets, circular streets in garden cities and towers in the park. Draw a map of how you'd layout an ideal neighborhood.
challenges.title: Map Your Neighborhood

challenges.description: Observe people using different urban spaces. Upload photos or videos of elements that just aren't working like they should and suggest why. No crosswalk? Narrow sidewalk?
challenges.title: Find a Spot Needing Improvement

challenges.description: Draw an illustration of your ideal neighborhood. How big are the buildings, how wide are the streets? What kind of shops or parks are nearby? What do you want from a neighborhood?
challenges.title: Draw a Fantasy Neighborhood

challenges.description: Pick an area you know well and draw a map that shows the function of each area of the neighborhood. Make sure to use colors and include a Legend, the guide that labels each zone.
challenges.title: Make a Zoning Map of Your Neighborhood

challenges.description: Make a Footprint Diagram that shows the bird's eye view of buildings in black and white. This makes it easier to see the layout of a city.
challenges.title: Draw a Footprint Diagram

challenges.description: Calculate the density of where you live, then upload your results. Density is determined by dividing the population by number of square miles they live on.
challenges.title: Calculate Density

challenges.description: Grab some yarn and cover something dull and ugly with a knitted or crocheted creation. Take a before and after picture to show the difference.
challenges.title: Go Yarn Bombing

challenges.description: Find the calendar for your city's Planning or Urban Design department and attend a meeting. Take a video or photo and tell us what was discussed!
challenges.title: Attend a Community Planning Meeting

challenges.description: Imagine a better city – then build it as a small model with at least 3 realistic buildings.
challenges.title: Build a Scale Model City

challenges.description: Upload screenshots of a SketchUp city you build yourself. SketchUp is an easier 3d program that allows you build shapes quickly.
challenges.title: Model a 3D City

challenges.description: You can become a part of change in your neighborhood or city. Find a way to get involved in building a parklet in a public place.
challenges.title: Build a Public Parklet

challenges.description: Prepare your animal's meal with healthy, natural ingredients that match the animal's dietary needs. Share a picture or video showing how you feed your pet a healthy meal.
challenges.title: Feed an Animal

challenges.description: Fur, feathers, shell, or scales, every animal likes having clean and healthy skin.  For best results, give these treatments on a regular basis.
challenges.title: Care for an Animal's Coat

challenges.description: Prepare a comfortable space an animal can call their own.
challenges.title: Make an Animal Home

challenges.description: Nobody likes having cold, sore, or cracked feet.  Use tools, make booties, or mix up a balm to help keep an animal on the move.
challenges.title: Care for an Animal's Feet

challenges.description: Many animals have active, inquisitive minds that love to learn.  Be a kind, consistent trainer so you can teach an animal the best way to behave.  Take a video of your animal performing the trick you taught it.
challenges.title: Train an Animal

challenges.description: Some animals need special care to keep their mouths strong and healthy, and all animals appreciate special snacks that support good teeth.
challenges.title: Care for an Animal's Mouth

challenges.description: Taking medication is an unpleasant process, but a good Vet can make it easy.  Video yourself practicing this skill.  You could also design and describe a creative way to make taking medication easier for a sick animal.
challenges.title: Make Medication Easier

challenges.description: Practice your first aid skills so you can be ready in any emergency!  If you can't find a live animal with a lot of patience, models, stuffed animals, and even humans can be useful substitutes.
challenges.title: Perform Animal First Aid

challenges.description: Much animal suffering results from the ignorance of animal owners.  Make a poster, video, or use some other method to share your knowledge and inform others about proper animal care.
challenges.title: Educate Animal Owners

challenges.description: It's important to study what's going on inside your patients.  Use your favorite materials to make an anatomical model of an animal so you can better understand their health.
challenges.title: Make an Anatomical Model

challenges.description: There are hundreds of unsolved problems in veterinary science and medicine, waiting for curious and determined minds to find the solution.  Document your discoveries with photos, charts, videos, or presentations.
challenges.title: Perform Veterinary Research

challenges.description: Vocalists are like athletes – they need to warm up before they perform.  Practice vocal warm ups to stretch and strengthen the organs that create your voice.  To see real improvement, do these every day! Share your warm up with a video.
challenges.title: Warm Up Your Voice

challenges.description: Sing a song or a made up melody on Do-Re-Mi! Share it with a video.
challenges.title: Sight Sing Using Solfège

challenges.description: Find the backtrack to one of your favorite songs and sing over it. Karaoke is even more fun when you do it with friends. Record your experience with a video.
challenges.title: Perform Karaoke

challenges.description: Make up a tune using boops, bops, and la la la's! Experiment with different vowels and voiced consonants. An improvised tune without words is called "scat". Share your scatting with a video.
challenges.title: Try Scat Singing

challenges.description: Sing in at least 3 different places – an auditorium, a bathroom, a parking lot, or outside. Record yourself each time and talk about how different spaces affect your voice.
challenges.title: Explore Acoustics

challenges.description: A show tune is any song from musical theater. Make sure you convey the emotions of the character you're acting out! Share your show tune with a video.
challenges.title: Belt a Show Tune

challenges.description: A folk song is typically one that has been passed down from many generations. Sing a cover, or write your own folk song to sing. Record it with a video.
challenges.title: Sing a Folk Song

challenges.description: Country music is a genre, which originated in the South of the US.  Singers are usually accompanied by acoustic instruments. Try playing guitar while you sing, and share your song with a video.
challenges.title: Sing a Country Song

challenges.description: Harmonies are made by two or more singers singing on different notes that work well together. Sing a harmony with a friend or two, and share it with a video.
challenges.title: Harmonize

challenges.description: Yodeling is a quick transition from a deep chest voice to a high head voice. Try copying a well known yodeling melody, and share it with a video.
challenges.title: Yodel

challenges.description: A chorus is a group of people that sing together. Share a pic or video of you on stage with your chorus. If you aren't in an official group, gather some friends or family members and sing a song together instead!
challenges.title: Join a Chorus

challenges.description: Create a custom rainbow loom bracelet.
challenges.title: Make a Rainbow Loom Bracelet

challenges.description: Make a series of loops with your hands and you'll get a woven bracelet, scarf, or belt in no time.
challenges.title: Finger Knit a Garment

challenges.description: Pom-poms are poofy balls that can be used to decorate hats, wall tapestries, or other woven creations. No fancy tools required: all you need is yarn, scissors, and some patience!
challenges.title: Make Pom-Poms

challenges.description: The best way for a Crochet newbie to learn basic skills is to begin with a simple square or strip. You'll learn to start, end and single crochet in between. You can always stitch the practice pieces together later into something.
challenges.title: Learn to Crochet

challenges.description: Upload a clear picture of a finished friendship or paracord bracelet.
challenges.title: Weave a Bracelet

challenges.description: Learn the basics of knitting by making a small knit square or strip. Knitting uses two needles, Crochet uses a single hook.
challenges.title: Learn to Knit

challenges.description: Felt is made by matting, tangling, condensing, and pressing together wool – usually with hot water. Sumerian legend states that after a long journey, the movement and hot sweat of the warriors had turned their wool socks into felt socks.
challenges.title: Make Felt

challenges.description: Crocheting or knitting a beanie cap is possible even for beginners. Hats are quick to make and never fall out of fashion or utility. They also tend to be prominently displayed – on top of someone's head!
challenges.title: Knit or Crochet a Hat

challenges.description: If you can knit or crochet a square, you're ready to make a scarf – it's just more rows! Scarves are practical and beautiful; they can make anyone look more sophisticated.
challenges.title: Make a Scarf

challenges.description: Woven materials are everywhere. Most fabrics are made from woven strands, as are hi-tech materials like super-strong carbon and fiberglass mesh. Start out with a Hair Braid or Bracelet until you’re ready to tackle a Hand Woven Rug or a Wicker Chair.
challenges.title: Weave

challenges.description: Weave something bright and cover something dull like a light pole or bike rack. Take a before and after picture to show the difference.
challenges.title: Go Yarn Bombing

challenges.description: There are an infinite number of possible combinations of knitting stitches, but there are certainly favorites. Explore different styles and find what feels best for you.
challenges.title: Develop Various Knitting Styles

challenges.description: If you live where it gets really cold, you probably keep your hands warm with a pair of heavy gloves. Crochet some fingerless gloves and have the best of both worlds: warmth and dexterity.
challenges.title: Make Fingerless Gloves

challenges.description: One of the best reasons to take up knitting is to be able to wrap yourself in a sweater of your own creation. It takes patience and an artists eye to make, but a good sweater is a thing that you will treasure your whole life.
challenges.title: Make a Sweater

challenges.description: To solve this challenge, upload screenshots of your favorite pieces of web design inspiration. Visit your favorite websites. Are they beautiful? Easy to use? Are there little details that you love in particular?
challenges.title: Gather Website Inspiration

challenges.description: After websites are designed, they're coded and uploaded to servers. Web designers don't always create the code, but it's helpful to understand the language. Explore basic HTML and CSS by remixing a website with Hackasaurus.
challenges.title: Remix a Website

challenges.description: Sketch a wireframe for a site and use the button kit if you've made one. Wireframes are how web designers try layout ideas before putting a lot of time into a detailed design.
challenges.title: Sketch Wireframes

challenges.description: From the template, draw your own set of website buttons, arrows, menus, sliders and banners. This sort of button kit is reused all over a website.
challenges.title: Create a Button Kit

challenges.description: Graphics applications can make experimentation fast and easy. Careful though, this process is for trying many quick ideas, not perfecting one idea – that will come next.
challenges.title: Design Digital Wireframes

challenges.description: Before a website is coded, designers finesse the details by making mockups in graphics applications like Photoshop or Gimp. These mockups should look almost exactly like the final, coded site will look.
challenges.title: Design Digital Mockups

challenges.description: Web designers most often design websites for a client. Find a friend or family member, learn about them and create the wireframes and digital mockup for a site based on their needs.
challenges.title: Design for a Client

challenges.description: Make a kite. Some favorites of kite lovers are Diamond, Delta, Box, Sled, and Stunt Kites.
challenges.title: Make a Kite

challenges.description: Make a parachute out of thin, light, and flexible material. The bigger the chute, the slower it falls. Record a video of your parachute as it slowly falls to the ground.
challenges.title: Make a Parachute

challenges.description: Make a toy whirlygig to demonstrate the principles of more functional wind devices. Share it in action with a video.
challenges.title: Make a Whirligig

challenges.description: Weather vanes are simple instruments that show the direction of wind, but not the speed. When properly designed they have two sides around a central pivot point that are unequal in surface area, but equal in weight. One side catches more wind and swings around.
challenges.title: Make a Weather Vane

challenges.description: To measure the speed of wind, you need a device called an Anemometer. They can come in many forms, some of which are easy to make yourself, like a wind sock. A simple ping pong ball anemometer was even used on the Phoenix Mars Lander.
challenges.title: Build an Anemometer

challenges.description: Sailboats work by harnessing the power of the wind.  The sails are built to resemble wings that captures wind which creates a force that moves the boat forwards. You can manipulate the rudder and the rigging to push your boat in a desired direction.
challenges.title: Build a Model Sailboat

challenges.description: Wind Turbines use rotating blades to transfer wind energy into mechanical energy. Historically, this energy was used to directly drive water pumps or to grind grains in what's called a windmill. Or, the energy can be used to generate electricity – wind power.
challenges.title: Build a Wind Turbine

challenges.description: The most elegant vehicle of all is the sailboat, as it uses only wind and water to propel forward. Find someone with a real sailboat and accompany them on their next outing. Share your sailing adventure with a video.
challenges.title: Sail a Boat

challenges.description: You can sail the wind on land using a skateboard, mountainboard, wagon, or recumbant tricycle. Slightly dangerous but incredibly fun.
challenges.title: Make a Landsail Vehicle

challenges.description: Parafoils are kites that don't have rigid frames, but instead hold their shape as wind is pushed into cells that are built into their fabric structures. Capture your parafoil in action with a video.
challenges.title: Make a Parafoil

challenges.description: The artist Theo Jansen invented the "Strandbeest" and other walking machines that use sails to trigger the life-like movement of a lightweight skeleton. These kinetic sculptures can also be made at a small scale.
challenges.title: Make a Wind Powered Walker

challenges.description: To really understand the way wind acts upon objects, it is very useful to simulate its effects. This can be done with a computer or with built controlled environments.
challenges.title: Simulate Wind

challenges.description: Building a worthy sea craft is a noble challenge. With the proper plans and a lot of hard work, you can build your sailboat. When your sailboat is finished, it should not only hold you up on the water, but propel you forward.
challenges.title: Make a Sailboat

challenges.description: Paint, varnish, or oil something wooden. A finish can make wood look beautiful and prevent it from weathering and rotting.
challenges.title: Finish or Paint a Wood Project

challenges.description: Create a wooden box that's as beautiful as it is functional.
challenges.title: Build a Wooden Box

challenges.description: Make a dog, cat, or bird house. Build a shelter that an animal would love to live in.
challenges.title: Build an Animal Dwelling

challenges.description: Whittlers and carvers remove wood from a block, sculpting an object into shape. By slowly and carefully cutting and paring away, they bring to life wooden treasures and useful implements. They can even use curved knives to make concave shapes like bowls and spoons.
challenges.title: Whittle or Carve a Tool or Sculpture

challenges.description: Laminated boards are super strong and used in all kinds of things, like skateboards, tables, cutting boards, clocks, and chairs. By combining different types and shades of wood, you can create a one of a kind look that's super strong.
challenges.title: Make a Laminated Board

challenges.description: A storage space can hold anything from a pile of books to a collection of handmade quilts. Some types of storage have locking lids that keep items safe and secure, while other storage, such as shelves, can prominently display something beautiful and unique.
challenges.title: Build a Storage Space

challenges.description: Woodworking is so much easier when you keep your work-space neat and your tools organized. Take a video and explain your organizing methods.
challenges.title: Organize Your Tools

challenges.description: Sanding brings out a natural wood grain, makes your surface nice to touch, and takes away splinters. The idea is to start with rough sandpaper, then use finer and finer grain until it is smooth. Sand something you've made to bring out its natural beauty.
challenges.title: Sand a Wood Project

challenges.description: Learn to drill and use screws to construct a wooden object! Screws are strong, simple and fun to attach. Drilling a slightly smaller hole first is a good way to prevent wood from splitting when you put in a screw. Take a video of your efforts.
challenges.title: Drill and Screw

challenges.description: Saws have been around for thousands of years. There are all kinds of saws – hand saws, circular saws, miter saws, table saws, and more. Use a saw to make a project with joints that are tight and clean.
challenges.title: Saw Wood

challenges.description: Clamping is like an extra pair of arms that lets the woodworker hold their project in place while they glue, drill or screw. Use a clamp to hold your project in place as you work. This may sound easy, but it takes a steady hand to ensure it's done right.
challenges.title: Clamp a Wood Project

challenges.description: Joinery has been around for centuries, long before screws were invented. Some joints, like a butt joint, are simple to learn, while others, like the dovetail, take years and years of practice to perfect. Craft something entirely without glue or screw.
challenges.title: Join a Corner

challenges.description: Planes are used on rough cuts of wood to flatten, square, and smooth a surface. Planers can range in size from small hand planers to powerful motorized ones. Learn to use a planar to bring the surface of your project to perfection.
challenges.title: Plane Wood

challenges.description: Write a story that is only one sentence long. Spelling, punctuation, and grammar all count for this challenge!  Keep an eye out for run-on sentences!
challenges.title: Write a One-Sentence Story

challenges.description: Pick a character from a story and describe them well. Upload a video, a clear picture of text, or JustPaste.it.
challenges.title: Describe a Character

challenges.description: Write a poem and upload a picture of the text, a link to JustPasteIt.it, or a video of you reciting it. It can be a sonnet, limerick, haiku, or free verse.
challenges.title: Write a Poem

challenges.description: Short stories aren't that short. Write a story that has a plot and develops characters. Copy your story to Justpaste.it and put a link in the comments.
challenges.title: Write a Short Story

challenges.description: Pick a book, read it, and then give a video review. Try and keep it around 1-minute long.
challenges.title: Review a Book

challenges.description: A journal or diary is a great place to keep track of your daily adventures or thoughts about life. Keep a journal for a few days, and share a picture or video of one of your written entries.
challenges.title: Share a Journal Entry

challenges.description: Take a video as you perform slam poetry. Don't just read what you wrote. Put your heart into it!
challenges.title: Perform Slam Poetry

challenges.description: Write a review for a book, article, movie, or anything else you can think of. Post it to JustPaste.it and share the link in your comments.
challenges.title: Write a Review

challenges.description: Pick a story that you love and re-write the ending. Be funny, witty, shocking and entertaining. Paste it in JustPaste.it and post a link.
challenges.title: Invent an Alternative Ending

challenges.description: Have a friend or teacher edit your writing. Be sure to show the edits.
challenges.title: Have Someone Edit Your Writing

challenges.description: Write a narrative, descriptive, expository or persuasive essay. Copy it to Justpaste.it and provide a link in your comments.
challenges.title: Write an Essay

challenges.description: Start a blog and write at least 3 entries. Post a link to it in the comments.
challenges.title: Start a Blog

challenges.description: Find a writing contest for your essay, short story or poem and enter it. Take screenshots and copy it to JustPaste.it with a link.
challenges.title: Enter a Writing Contest

challenges.description: Whether you dig out a cave or build a fortress with snow bricks, build something sturdy. Take a picture of yourself inside your structure.
challenges.title: Construct a Snow Shelter

challenges.description: Use this technique of the Inuit people to protect yourself from the sun's reflection on the snow. Use a lasting material, like wood. Snap a photo.
challenges.title: Make Snow Goggles

challenges.description: A yeti's favorite dessert! Scoop up some snow and mix with a few simple ingredients to make this ancient winter treat. Try mixing with experimental flavors!
challenges.title: Make Snow Cream

challenges.description: Learn to glide gracefully on skis, skates and boards – over mountains, hills, and frozen pools. Share a picture or take a video of you performing a winter sport.
challenges.title: Learn a Winter Sport

challenges.description: The unique properties of snow make it an ideal tool for artistic expression. Make an epic snow creature worthy of a Yeti, and snap a photo of it.
challenges.title: Create a Snow Creature

challenges.description: Keeping warm is key to surviving the cold. Use what you have and make something warm to wear. Take a video and explain how you made it, or snap pictures showing the details.
challenges.title: Make Something Warm to Wear

challenges.description: Prepare fire starters using various materials like sawdust, dryer lint and wax. Tell us how you made your fire starter and take a video of it burning.
challenges.title: Make Fire Starters

challenges.description: You never know when a blizzard will blow past you. Make your own kit for your backpack or family's car in case of a snow emergency.
challenges.title: Make a Winter Survival Kit

challenges.description: Stew is a staple of winter survival. Share your ingredients and snap a photo of your steaming hot stew.
challenges.title: Cook Stew

challenges.description: Build a device to launch snowballs to keep strangers at a distance. Take a video and show how far you can launch a ball of snow.
challenges.title: Invent a Snowball Launcher

challenges.description: Snowshoes make it possible for people to walk on snow. Build a pair from wood, plastic, even cardboard. Take a video and walk around in them.
challenges.title: Make Snowshoes

challenges.description: If maple trees grow near your home, you can perform this technique. Carefully tap your trees and boil the sap. Video the whole process.
challenges.title: Produce Maple Syrup

challenges.description: Sleds are the ultimate winter vehicle. Make your own sled using a traditional design or your own invention. Take a video of it in action.
challenges.title: Build a Sled

challenges.description: Turn a yard into a fantasy. Build sled ramps, a luge, or even an ice rink! Invite over your friends and take a video showing what you made. Share your efforts with a video.
challenges.title: Build a Winter Playground

challenges.description: Discover an animal in the wild – not in a Zoo, and not your dog – and take a photograph or video.
challenges.title: Photograph an Animal in the Wild

challenges.description: Build a house or habitat for wild animals.
challenges.title: Build a Wildlife Habitat

challenges.description: Make a picture or sculpture of a creature that could have existed, or might actually be out there...
challenges.title: Design a Fantasy Animal

challenges.description: Animals are often difficult to see, and Zoologists must be able to read the clues they've left behind.  Footprints, scat, hair, and nests are just some of the evidence you might find. Find and identify these, if you can.
challenges.title: Track a Wild Animal

challenges.description: One of the biggest things threatening animals today is the pollution and destruction of their habitats.  Design and build a device to reverse the effects of pollution in an ecosystem.
challenges.title: Protect the Wild from Trash

challenges.description: You can learn a lot about what an animal eats by what it leaves behind.  Because many owls swallow their pray whole, you may find the complete skeleton of an owl's victim jumbled up inside an owl pellet.
challenges.title: Dissect an Owl Pellet

challenges.description: Animals are intricately linked to their surroundings.  Choose an animal and research it's natural habitat, including the other living things that are it's food, neighbors, or predators.  Create a model, or even a home, for a real animal.
challenges.title: Create a Habitat Diorama

challenges.description: Humans are not the only animals to use sounds to communicate. Some of them have even been found to have words and a language all their own. Others use sound to locate themselves and their prey.  Find a quiet place, listen – record what you hear.
challenges.title: Make Audio Recordings of the Wild

challenges.description: Many kinds of amphibians and aquatic animals undergo metamorphosis, starting out life in one form or habitat, and changing to something very different as they grow.  Use your favorite process (drawing, sculpture, video, etc.) to model this change.
challenges.title: Make a Model of Metamorphosis

challenges.description: While you can purchase preserved specimens prepared especially for dissection, you can learn a lot about an animal's inner workings by dissecting earthworms or insects you find in the ground.  Remember to wear gloves and clean your equipment!
challenges.title: Perform an Animal Dissection

challenges.description: Can't dissect a real animal?  Want to keep your results for study and display?  Make a model of the inner workings of an animal instead!
challenges.title: Make an Anatomical Model

challenges.description: Zoologists will put different animals in mazes to test their ability to learn.  Design a maze for ants, worms, rats, dogs, humans or some other animal and see how long it takes them to learn it.
challenges.title: Create and Test an Animal Maze
